title: 109_hr4318
content: The "Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act" terminates prohibitions on expenditures for offshore gas leasing and revokes withdrawals of Federal submerged lands for leasing. It also introduces state approval requirements for gas leasing on the Outer Continental Shelf. SEC. 10 of the Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act requires State approval for gas leasing within 20 miles of a State's coastline. Additionally, at least 75 percent of available unleased acreage within each planning area must be offered for gas leasing in each 5-year program. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allocate a percentage of bonus bids and royalties from new Federal gas leases to States and the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allocates a percentage of bonus bids and royalties from new Federal gas leases to States and the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. Additionally, existing gas leases on submerged lands within State boundaries receive a percentage of amounts received in the first and second full fiscal years after the enactment of the Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allocates a percentage of bonus bids and royalties from new Federal gas leases to States and the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. For existing gas leases on submerged lands within State boundaries, the percentage of amounts received increases over the years, starting at 10 percent in the first full fiscal year after enactment and reaching 40 percent in the fourth year and beyond. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allocates a percentage of bonus bids and royalties from new Federal gas leases to States and the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. For existing gas leases on submerged lands within State boundaries, the percentage of amounts received increases over the years, starting at 10 percent in the first full fiscal year after enactment and reaching 40 percent in the fourth year and beyond. The percentage of total amounts of bonus bids and royalties from tracts subject to subparagraph (A) or (B) in a State is equivalent to the percentage of surface acreage within seaward boundaries. Definitions for existing and new federal gas leases are provided in this paragraph. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act grants bonus bids and royalties to States and the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. State seaward boundaries are established and extended lines are indicated on maps for each outer Continental Shelf region. SEC. 5. NATURAL GAS-ONLY LEASING. Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow the Secretary to issue leases for the development and production of natural gas and associated condensate. Regulations must be followed regarding the definition of natural gas, condensate, and oil, as well as the rights and obligations of the lessee. Procedures are also established for handling oil deposits discovered during exploration or development. The Secretary can issue natural gas-only leases for the Outer Continental Shelf under certain regulations and requirements. Existing oil and gas leases can be restricted to natural gas and associated condensate only upon request. The Secretary may issue natural gas-only leases before June 30, 2007, without amending the program for 2002-2007. The Secretary can issue natural gas-only leases for the Outer Continental Shelf without amending existing programs. Leases can be issued for the periods 2002-2007 and 2007-2012, with public notice and comment opportunities required.
